content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: good example of regular expressions

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very good contribution ! Not always easy to deal with these kind of problems !

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Its a interesting test and i think it would fit really well into this platform!
I would hope you republish this! I think it's important for more people to learn regular expressions. I would upvote this again!! Thanks for your submission

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This could teach how to reverse strings, while also considering the placement of a specific string inside a sentence

Goal
* Paragraph 1: Please fix the typo: "langage" => "language".

* Paragraph 1: Please change "StrInv(" to "StrInv".

Stub generator
* Please change "line" to "message" for consistency.

Thanks.

By the way, the ultimate test is not by me, but by the guy behind https://silent-tower.net/, with whom we had fun with a chat bot I made back in 2016. This was the final boss to see if my bot worked correctly, answering itself; and it did!

(although looking at it now, the code was crappy and it's plain luck it worked like it did)

Hello,

In the "Input" and "Constraits" sections you can pass {{message}} to [[message]].
In the "Output", you forgot to repeat the 3 possibilities : "The StrInv result, {{(nothing to display)}} or {{(nothing to reverse)}}"
In your tests, can you invert validator 1 and test 2, so that your tests and validators remain constant?

Also in the statement, can you be more assertive about the fact that it can only have one : "StrInv" ? 

Finaly, what do you mean by "You must not escape the result" ?

Thanks for the corrections! Some follow-ups:

- I'm not sure what you mean by inverting validator 1 and test 2 (now validator 2 and test 1, I've inverted the two first pairs because the full sentence demonstrates better what input should be received)? Test/validator 1 demonstrate the use of StrInv "in a sentence", and test/validator 2 is "alone".

- I've now explicited "that may contain a single StrInv function call". What about now? :-)

- I've removed the "You must not escape the result" mention, as you're right, it was confusing. Instead, I've just added more examples to demonstrate what I meant.
Thanks for the review, I've applied the changes :)

- I'm thinking of inverting "I see, but what about StrInv("gen z")?" with "StrInv("abc")" so that the space test and the validator run simultaneously

- Yeah, I think it's good

Sorry about that but you forgot the brackets around "nothing to display" in the "Output" :/

Oh! Good point about the space test. I've just reversed just the contents of StrInv to support this.

(and thanks for the missing parenthesis, you're right, it's hard to see in the code behind the field >_>)
